2 factor authentication.definition: An extra layer of security used to make sure that people trying to gain access to an online account are who they say they are.

51% attack.definition: An attack on blockchain consensus by controlling over 51% of the block producing power on the network.

address.definition: Unique public identifier for an entity on a blockchain

allowance.definition: Allows an entity, usually a smart contract, the right to use a specified amount of your tokens in a transaction

alternative layer 1.definition: Layer 1 blockchains other than Ethereum and Bitcoin.

bet.definition: risking money in exchange for greater rewards (shorting/longing) ; money verb on the skill cube

block.definition: A group of transactions on the blockchain.

block explorer.definition: Search and exploration tool for blockchain data

block hash.definition: The unique identifier for each block file. Each new block refers to the block hash of the previous block to form the single-file connected blockchain.

block reward.definition: The amount of a blockchain’s native asset given to the proposer of a new valid block.

block space.definition: The amount of space on a blockchain that can be used to store information and run code. The amount of “space” within one (or a series of) block(s).

blockchain.definition: A shared, unchangeable database, or ledger, of recorded transactions.

blockchain architecture.definition: The structures for how data is stored in blockchain technology.

blockchain trilemma.definition: The problem describing the need for all 3 mutually-interfering blockchain qualities: Security, Scalability, and Decentralization.

borrower.definition: Willing to pay interest to lenders in order to borrow assets

censorship-resistant.definition: No government or company has control to determine what is or is not allowed.

centralized exchange.definition: (CEX) Platform that coordinates cryptocurrency trading for a fee, similar to a stock exchange

chain.definition: Binds blocks of data together to form a database which cannot be altered or changed.

coin.definition: The native asset of a blockchain mostly used as a form of currency to facilitate transactions on the network.

cold wallet.definition: A type of non-custodial wallet that is stored offline and does not require a perpetual internet connection.

cold wallets.definition: A type of non-custodial wallet that is stored offline and does not require a perpetual internet connection.

collateral.definition: A borrower's pledge of specific asset(s) to a lender, to secure repayment of a loan

consensus.definition: Agreement, trust, and security across a decentralized computer network like blockchains.

custodial wallet.definition: With a custodial wallet, another party controls the private keys, thus controlling access to your crypto assets.

custodial wallets.definition: With a custodial wallet, another party controls the private keys, thus controlling access to your crypto assets.

dapp.definition: Digital applications or programs that exist and run on a blockchain, and are outside the purview and control of a single authority.

dapps.definition: Digital applications or programs that exist and run on a blockchain, and are outside the purview and control of a single authority.

decentralization.definition: Principle that no single authority or entity should control the blockchain data.

decentralized.definition: No single authority or entity controls the data.

decentralized exchange.definition: (DEX) protocol that facilitates exchange without requiring trusted intermediaries

dex aggregator.definition: Protocol that combines DEX liquidity from multiple sources in one interface

digital signature.definition: The unique identifier for each user that serves the function of personal stamps or physical signatures in the digital space.

earn.definition: contributing value in exchange for rewards ; money verb on the skill cube

epoch.definition: The time taken for a specific number of blocks to be included on any particular blockchain.

finality.definition: How long it takes until it is safe to trust that a new transaction is valid and final.

fomo.definition: Fear Of Missing Out. Anxiety or apprehension about missing out on or not getting things

gasless transactions.definition: A transaction that pays gas using some of the token to be traded rather than the native coin of the blockchain network

gwei.definition: A unit used on Ethereum blockchain, equivalent to 0.000000001 ETH (one billionth), used commonly to describe gas prices

hardware wallet.definition: A type of non-custodial wallet that stores private keys offline in a physical hardware device.

hashing function.definition: A function that is easy to calculate in one direction only, making it nearly impossible to reverse engineer the inputs and functionally guaranteeing unique outputs for a given input.

hodl.definition: Hold On for Dear Life. Crypto slang for not selling crypto no matter what the market conditions are

hot wallet.definition: A type of non-custodial wallet that is perpetually connected to the internet.

hot wallets.definition: A type of non-custodial wallet that is perpetually connected to the internet.

intermediary token.definition: A token that is part of the middle of a trade route, not the starting or ending token

invest.definition: The act of buying a coin/token that uses DeFi technology

layer 2.definition: A blockchain that extends Ethereum scalability while inheriting Ethereum security.

ledger.definition: The record of all transactions that have ever occurred.

liquidity.definition: How much of a token is available for trading

liquidity pool.definition: A pool of tokens in a DEX that facilitates permissionless trades between two tokens

liquidity pools.definition: A liquidity pool is a crowdsourced pool of cryptocurrencies or tokens locked in a smart contract that is used to facilitate trades between the assets on a decentralized exchange (DEX)

meta-aggregator.definition: A tool that brings together other aggregators into an extra overview layer

mev.definition: Maximal extractible value - value extracted by ordering transactions within blocks

non-custodial wallet.definition: With a non-custodial wallet, you have sole control of your private keys, which in turn control your crypto assets.

non-custodial wallets.definition: With a non-custodial wallet, you have sole control of your private keys, which in turn control your crypto assets.

otc.definition: (Over the Counter) Trades made directly with private entities

over the counter.definition: (OTC) Trades made directly with private entities

peer-to-peer.definition: A transaction between two parties that does not require a middleman or controlling entity.

permissionless.definition: Refers to a public blockchain that anyone can use to buy, sell, or trade assets.

phishing.definition: A type of social engineering attack where the attacker poses as a trusted person or organization to trick victims into sharing sensitive information or sending them money

poap.definition: A POAP (Proof of Attendance Protocol) is a badge that keeps a reliable record of life experiences in your wallet, like for example successfully completing a lesson.

price impact.definition: The amount prices on a DEX change due to the trade size

private key.definition: A private key allows access to your wallet in order for you to send crypto assets to other address.

private keys.definition: A private key allows access to your wallet in order for you to send crypto assets to other address.

proof of stake.definition: Blockchain Consensus algorithms that randomly choose a block producer based on the amount of stake each entity has locked into the protocol.

proof of work.definition: Blockchain Consensus algorithms that rely on “work” done by miners competing to create valid blocks by proposing blocks and seeing if each one has a valid hash.

public.definition: Public blockchains allow anyone to view the blockchain ledger

public key.definition: A public key is your address. It gives others a point of reference to send crypto assets to you.

public keys.definition: A public key is your address. It gives others a point of reference to send crypto assets to you.

recovery phrase.definition: A recovery phrase is a list of 12 to 24 words which is used to generate your wallet's public key and private key.

recovery phrases.definition: A recovery phrase is a list of 12 to 24 words which is used to generate your wallet's public key and private key.

sandwich attack.definition: A hidden cost for users due to ordering of transactions by block producers

scalability.definition: A blockchain’s capability to handle a growing amount of work, transactions, and usage with minimal disruption for users.

scam-token.definition: A cryptocurrency token that is launched for the sole purpose of stealing investor funds

security.definition: Ability of a blockchain to withstand hacking attempts, code exploits, and economic exploits among other attacks, and continue to function as normal.

seed phrase.definition: Group of random words generated by a wallet on setup, they act as the master key to ALL accounts controlled by that wallet. NEVER SHARE YOUR SEED PHRASE WITH ANYONE FOR ANY REASON.

sharding.definition: The process of splitting a single blockchain into multiple chains that all run together in parallel to increase scalability.

slippage tolerance.definition: How much can prices change before your trade executes

smart contract.definition: Computerized code that execute terms of a contract automatically

social engineering.definition: Manipulating someone into sharing sensitive or confidential information such as passwords or seed phrases

spend.definition: Using your crypto assets to pay for goods or services.

stake.definition: The amount of a financial asset locked into a cryptocurrency protocol. It represents someone’s financial commitment to the protocol, their “skin in the game”.

staking.definition: The temporary commitment of a portion of your crypto into a smart contract for a specified amount of time in exchange for earning interest ("rewards")

swap.definition: A trade from one token to another

tokens.definition: Units that can stand for assets or deeds that are built on an existing blockchain.

tps.definition: A measure of a blockchains scalability, TPS is the number of transactions per second processed by a blockchain.

trade.definition: exchanging assets or money for something valuable ; money verb on the skill cube

trade routes.definition: What is the path taken from starting token to ending token in a trade

trade routing.definition: Planning the path taken from starting token to ending token in a trade

transaction hash.definition: The unique identifier for each transaction; it is derived from the transaction data, the digital signature of the transaction sender, and a one-time use number to avoid duplicate transactions.

transaction throughput.definition: How many transactions a blockchain can process at once, usually measured in transactions per second (TPS).

wallet.definition: A wallet is an application or device used to send and receive crypto assets on the blockchain.

wallets.definition: A wallet is an application or device used to send and receive crypto assets on the blockchain.

web3.definition: Refers to applications that run on the blockchain and allow anyone to participate without monetizing their personal data.
